title: Text Input
reference-overview: The Text Input element is the field in which the user can enter text on a form.
reference-usage: Use the Text Input element when a user is required to enter a small amount of text on a form. For longer content, use the Text Area element.
reference-details:
• Text Input should default to the Attention/Highlight border color when the user clicks inside the box.
  • The Input Label should always be in Title Case.
  • Text Input should be adapted so it can be used with Placeholder Text if desired.
  • Text Input should be adapted so it can be used with an Icon preceding it if the designer wants to forgo a Label. An example of this would be using an icon of a cell phone for preceding a Text Input that requires the user to enter a phone number.
  • Text Input should be adapted so it can be used with a button, like if the Text Input is being used as a search function.
  • Text Input should be adapted so it can be used with add on text after the field, like adding the word, dollars or the abbreviation for pounds (lbs).
reference-mobile:
The font size will increase slightly.

The input box will stretch 100% of the available width.
reference-technical:
Cross browser compatibility

IE9 doesn't support rounded corners on inputs, so we square the corners of the inputs so it looks just like IE8.
